title: The Lanesborough in London is Britain's most expensive hotel
text:
View
comments
Here's a Quote: from Lewis Carroll on the breakfast menu at The Lanesborough. 'Why, sometimes, I've believed as many as six impossible things before breakfast.'
One impossible thought for some people could be: how on earth will I settle my bill? Because this is the most expensive hotel in Britain — by a long chalk.
Overlooking Hyde Park Corner, The Lanesborough is an opulent recreation of 18th-century Regency London, where the cheapest room costs £720 a night.
The Lanesborough is an opulent recreation of 18th-century Regency London with rooms starting from £720 a night
For those who wish, a Royale Breakfast is an optional extra, and doesn't come cheap at £65 per person
Add in the Royale Breakfast at £65 per person (plus a 15 per cent service charge) and you're looking at £870 B&B.
A couple of cocktails followed by dinner and wine in Celeste will set you back a further £400 per couple for the seven-course tasting menu, bringing the total to nearly £1,300.
This is nothing compared with a night in the Royal Suite, where the price jumps to £31,200.
Yes, you get seven bedrooms, seven bathrooms, two living rooms and a dining room, but it's still a lot of spinach.
When we arrived on a Friday evening, our Uber taxi (the hotel would have laid on its Rolls-Royce Phantom if only we had asked) was surrounded as if it were a super-charged F1 racing car making an emergency pit stop.

An Inspector Calls: Welcoming and well-positioned, The... Our bags vanished within seconds only to appear in our room long before we got there.
We were escorted down the handsome limestone corridor by various members of staff, all of whom could become the new face of L'Oreal if they ever need a career change.
En route, we passed three original paintings by Sir Joshua Reynolds and learned later that the hotel has the largest collection of 18th-century paintings in the world outside any gallery.
It was 7.30pm, but an Arab couple were still enjoying afternoon tea in the yellow Withdrawing Room and the pianist was loosening up in the Library Bar next door.
Management of The Lanesborough — which was built as a private house by Viscount Lanesborough in 1719 before becoming the original St George's Hospital — was taken over 18 months ago by the German Oetker group.
An interior view of a spectacular dining area at the Lanesborough hotel in London, England
The Lanesborough's 93 guest rooms and suites, and all public areas have recently undergone an 18-month refurbishment

The revamp cost the building's owners, the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, a reported £80million and involved 300 craftsmen, including embroiderers, stencillers, trompe l'oeil experts and specialists in working with 23¼ carat gold leaf — of which there is a great deal.
There are three staff to each guest — and the service is impeccable.
We were upgraded to a suite without having to ask. It had a giant canopied bed, marble bathroom, huge chandelier, chintz sofa and chairs, lacquered dining room table (plus silver candelabra which would have had Liberace drooling).
There were two TVs, one housed in a gilt frame on the wall, the other hidden at the foot of the bed in a shiny cabinet, which rose into the air at the press of a button.
The only real concession to the 21st century were two infuriating Sony tablets, which turn lamps on and off, control the temperature, summon the butler and open and close the curtains.
The most lavish accommodation at the hotel is the seven-bedroom Royal Suite (pictured), which is £31,200 for the night
An interior view of the five-star Lanesborough hotel, once of the most lavish hotels in London, with personal butlers for guests
But it refused to open or close the curtains and I couldn't get to grips with the lighting — though I liked the way night lights came on when your feet touched the floor in the pitch dark.
Toiling in the kitchen is Florian Favario, a protege of Eric Frechon, whose restaurant at Le Bristol in Paris has three Michelin stars.
You can tell he's aiming for something similar by offering a starter called 'Cauliflower', which is really an over-sized canape of two florets creamed and roasted, infused with curry oil plus a sprinkling of parmesan cheese. Good, though.
And you know you're in Michelin territory when you start longing for a side order of chips to go with your fillet steak or lamb chops, but my goodness both were delicious.
We opted for a table in the middle of the powder blue room and sat side by side on an upholstered sofa.
Three massive chandeliers hung from the domed glass roof, illuminating the delicate bas-relief friezes, Wedgwood china and sculpted busts mounted on the walls.
At breakfast, our fruit salad was adorned with tiny strips of edible gold leaf curled around the strawberries. The full English was the best ever.
That was when we read the Lewis Carroll Quote: and took some comfort from it because amid the push for perfection and the money invested in this spectacular addition to the capital, no one had noticed that Carroll is spelt with two Rs.
